awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Establishing the microtubule-actin crosstalk in the preprophase band by the rice kinesin OsKCH2
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies the fundamental mechanisms that regulate cell division and growth of the rice plant and is expected to have a broad spectrum of societal impacts. First, findings from this project will impact future breeding of rice, which feeds half of the world's population. Second, scientists at both Oregon State University and University of California in Davis will be trained in multi-disciplinary areas by participating in the discovery-oriented research. Third, this project contains light microscopy-based short courses and hands-on training opportunities for underserved students, which will stimulate their interests in STEM disciplines. In addition, to increase public awareness of cutting-edge research programs, plant motor proteins will be included as living examples in advanced light microscopy workshops for high school and community college science teachers.

Specifically, this project is aimed at investigating how OsKCH2, a plant-specific kinesin in the rice plant Oryza sativa, enables the crosstalk between microtubules (MTs) and filamentous actins (F-actins) at the cortical division site and how it regulates cell division. Kinesins are motor proteins that use the energy from ATP hydrolysis to power numerous essential cellular processes such as transporting cargos along MTs and organizing/remodeling physiologically important MT-based arrays. OsKCH2 belongs to the group of Kinesins with a Calponin Homology domain (KCHs) in high plants. KCHs are known to crosslink MTs and F-actin in vitro, but their functions in plant growth and development remain poorly understood. The project is based on several critical preliminary findings including: (1) mutations in OsKCH2 caused a dwarfism phenotype, (2) OsKCH2 is specifically associated with the PPB during early stages of mitosis, (3) OsKCH2 directly binds to and transports F-actin on microtubules in vitro, and (4) OsKCH2 is the first minus end-directed Kinesin-14 to demonstrate processive motility as a single dimer.  This project will use a multi-disciplinary approach to address two objectives: (1) dissecting the regulatory mechanism underlying the processive motility of OsKCH2 using in vitro single-molecule imaging, and (2) interrogating the in vivo functions of OsKCH2 in cell division and plant growth by examining phenotypes linked to a null kch2 mutation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This award was aimed at understanding the motility mechanism of OsKCH2, a kinesin-14 motor in the rice plant Oryza sativa. To that end, we systematically investigated the motility of OsKCH2 using total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy. Our investigations revealed that OsCH2 is a novel kinesin-14 motor that contains the ability to unique exhibit processive (continuous) motility toward microtubule minus ends as individual homodimers and that the ability of OsCH2 to achieve microtubule minus-end-directed processivity requires a short stretch of amino acid residues immediately after the motor domain. In addition, our investigations led to two other significant findings related to kinesin-14 motility: 1) We showed that GiKIN14a, a kinesin-14 from an ancient eukaryote Giardia intestinalis, uses its N-terminal tail domain to achieve long-distance motility toward microtubule minus-ends as individual homodimers; 2) We showed that KlpA, a kinesin-14 motor from the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans, is the first kinesin-14 motor that uniquely exhibits processive motility toward microtubule plus ends as individual homodimers. During the funding period, we also developed a novel method that allows scientists to create artificial kinesin heterodimers that contain a pair of motor domains with different properties. Collectively, results generated from this award have markedly expanded the diversity of kinesin-14s and contributed significantly to current understanding of kinesin-14 motility. Research supported by this award contributed to a total of 10 peer reviewed publications (see the references at the end of this report), including 2 research articles in Nature Communications and 2 research articles in Current Biology.    

 

Broader impacts. Three graduate students (Andrew Popchock, Allison Gicking and Guangxi Feng), 1 postdoc (Kuo-Fu Tseng) and 7 undergraduate students (Vi Lam, Youngmin Park, Jeremy Meinke, Alexander Jones, Audrey Korte, and Healyn Epp) were trained by participating in this project. All three graduate students have successfully obtained their doctoral degrees; G. Feng is now working fulltime in the industrial sector, and A. Popchock and A. Gicking are postdoctoral researchers at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center and Penn State University respectively. K.-F. Tseng is currently a Chief Scientific Officer at Aetio Biotherapy. Two of the participating undergraduate students were accepted into graduate schools during the award period (Y. Park, Ohio State University; J. Meinke, Arionza State University). Broader impacts were also made by hosting multiple one-day advanced light microscopy workshops for high school students, teachers, and local community college science teachers. 

 

References (*= Co-First Authorship; #=Corresponding Authorship

  1. Tseng K.-F.*, Mickolajczyk K.J.*, Feng G.X.*, Feng Q.Z., Kwok E.S., Howe J., Barbar E.J., Dawson S.C., Hancock W.O., and Qiu W.H.# (2021) The tail of kinesin-14a in Giardia is a dual regulator of motility. Cur. Biol. 30:3664-3671.e4.
  2. Swentowsky K.W.*, Gent J.I., Lowry E.G., Schubert V, Ran X, Tseng K.-F., Harkess AE, Qiu W.H., Dawe R.K.# (2020) Distinct kinesin motors drive two types of maize neocentromeres. Genes Dev. 34:1239-1251.
  3. Gicking A.M.*, Wang P.*, Liu C., Mickolajczyk K.J., Guo L.J., Hancock W.O., and Qiu W.H.# (2019) The orphan kinesin PAKRP2 achieves processive motility via a noncanonical stepping mechanism. Biophys. J. 116:1270-1281.
  4. Popchock A.R., Jana S., Mehl R.A.#, and Qiu W.H.# (2018) Engineering heterodimeric kinesins through genetic incorporation of noncanonical amino acids. ACS Chem. Biol. 13: 2229–2236.  
  5. Gicking A.M., Swentowsky K.W., Dawe R.K.#, and Qiu W.H.# (2018) Functional diversification of the kinesin-14 family in land plants. FEBS Letters 592: 1918-1928.  
  6. Wang P.*, Tseng K.-F.*, Gao Y., Cianfrocco M., Guo L.J., and Qiu W.H.# (2018) The central stalk determines the motility of mitotic kinesin-14 homodimers. Cur. Biol. 28:2302-2308. 
  7. Gicking A.M., Qiu, W.H.#, and Hancock W.O.# (2018) Mitotic kinesins in action: Diffusive searching, directional switching and ensemble coordination. Mol. Biol. Cell, 29: 1153-1156. 
  8. Dawe R.K.#, Lowry E.G., Gent J.I., Stitzer M.C., Swentowski K.W., Higgins D.M., Ross-Ibarra J., Wallacem J.G., Kanizay L.B., Alabady M., Qiu W.H., Tseng K.-F., Wang N., Gao Z., Birchler J.A., Harkess A.E., Hodges A.L., and Hiatt E.N. (2018) A kinesin-14 motor activates neocentromeres to promote meiotic drive in Maize. Cell, 173, 839–850. 
  9. Tseng K.-F.*, Wang P.*, Lee Y.-R.*, Bowen J., Gicking A.M., Guo, L., Liu B.#, and Qiu W.H.#. (2018) The preprophase band-associated kinesin-14 OsKCH2 is a processive minus-end-directed microtubule motor. Nat. Commun., 9:1067.
  10. Popchock A.R.*, Tseng K.-F.*, Wang P., Karplus P.A., Xiang X., and Qiu W.H. (2017) The mitotic kinesin-14 KlpA contains a context-dependent directionality switch. Nat. Commun., 8, 13999.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Weihong Qiu
